title: Laws on Sacrifice and Blood
shortSummary: Leviticus 17 establishes strict regulations concerning the proper handling of sacrifices and the sacredness of blood. It emphasizes that all animal sacrifices must be brought to the tabernacle and that consuming blood is forbidden, underscoring the holiness of life and the atoning power of blood. These laws reinforce Israel’s covenant relationship with God and the importance of obedience in worship.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who receives God's commands and instructs the people of Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest and brother of Moses, responsible for overseeing sacrifices and priestly duties.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation of Israel who are commanded to follow God's laws regarding sacrifices and blood.

definitions.definition: The portable sanctuary where God’s presence dwelt among Israel and where sacrifices were offered.
Considered the life of the flesh; in Leviticus 17, blood is sacred and used for atonement on the altar.
A type of sacrifice expressing fellowship and gratitude to God, involving the burning of fat as a pleasing aroma.
A phrase indicating divine judgment resulting in exclusion from the community or death.

outline.heading: Command to Bring Sacrifices to the Tabernacle
outline.description: God commands that all animal sacrifices must be brought to the tabernacle’s entrance to be offered properly by the priests, forbidding unauthorized slaughter and pagan worship practices.

outline.heading: Prohibition Against Unauthorized Sacrifices
outline.description: This section reiterates that any burnt offering or sacrifice not brought to the tabernacle is forbidden and results in being cut off from the people.

outline.heading: Strict Prohibition Against Eating Blood
outline.description: God forbids the consumption of blood because it represents life and is reserved for atonement on the altar, emphasizing the sanctity of life and the seriousness of obedience.

outline.heading: Purification After Contact with Dead Animals
outline.description: Instructions are given for cleansing after eating animals that died naturally or were torn by beasts, highlighting the importance of ritual purity.

application: Approach worship with reverence and obedience, ensuring that all offerings and acts of devotion are done according to God’s instructions.
Recognize the sanctity of life as God’s gift and respect His commands regarding the use of blood and sacrifice.
Avoid syncretism by rejecting any form of worship or practice that deviates from biblical truth.
Maintain spiritual purity through repentance and obedience, understanding the need for cleansing from sin.

keyVerses.text: For the life of the flesh is in the blood: and I have given it to you upon the altar to make an atonement for your souls: for it is the blood that maketh an atonement for the soul.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the theological foundation for the sacredness of blood and its role in atonement, central to Israel’s worship and foreshadowing Christ’s sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: And whatsoever man there be of the house of Israel, or of the strangers that sojourn among you, that eateth any manner of blood; I will even set my face against that soul that eateth blood, and will cut him off from among his people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the seriousness of obeying God’s commands about blood, with severe consequences for disobedience.

keyVerses.text: And bringeth it not unto the door of the tabernacle of the congregation, to offer an offering unto the LORD before the tabernacle of the LORD; blood shall be imputed unto that man; he hath shed blood; and that man shall be cut off from among his people:
keyVerses.significance: This verse stresses the necessity of proper worship and the centrality of the tabernacle as the place God designated for sacrifices.
